trial_identification.studytitle: The effects of whole body vibration on the electromyographic activity of thigh muscles
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effects of whole body vibration on the electromyographic activity of thigh muscles in healthy male adults

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal musculoskeletal and cartilage development and function

interventions.interventions: The participants were randomised to receive each of the following interventions in a random order: control intervention, where participants performed squats in the platform, without vibration; squats with whole body vibration frequency of 25 Hz and squats with whole body vibration frequency of 50 Hz. The participants were invited to visit the facilities for 3 times and the cross-over trial had a wash out period of one week. The intervention was squatting with whole body vibration for 60 seconds, followed by 60 seconds of rest, with five repetitions. The exercises were supervised by physiotherapists trained in the method.
interventions.comparator: No secondary control group. The subjects will be their own control. The control intervention was squatting without whole body vibration for 60 seconds, followed by 60 seconds of rest, with five repetitions.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Electromyographic activity, expressed by the route mean square, of both quadriceps vastus, semimembranosus and semitendinosus muscles, bilaterally.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: The electromyographic activity was assessed for 30 seconds before each exposure, for 60 seconds during each squatting and for 30 seconds after the exposure.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Perceived subjective effort, measured with the Borg Scale.

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: musculoskeletal surgeries, lesions or alterations of the spine and lower limbs, cardiovascular or metabolic diseases.

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Assuming alpha, 2-tailed, is set at .05, for an effect size of 0.65, and a priori analysis, for Anova repeated measures, within factors, we would need a sample of 8 participants, with 3 repetitions of measurements, to yield power of 95%. Descriptive and Inferential analysis.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: UNIVERSIDADE FERNANDO PESSOA Praca 9 de Abril, 349, 4249-004 Porto

fundingsource.fundingaddress: UNIVERSIDADE FERNANDO PESSOA Praca 9 de Abril, 349, 4249-004 Porto

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Introduction: Whole body vibration exercises consist in performing exercise on a platform which transmits mechanical stimuli (vibration) to the anatomic area in contact with the platform and that propagate throughout the body. Objective: The aim of the present study is to analyze the electromyographic response of the thigh muscles exposed to different vibrational frequencies, when compared to a non vibration condition. Methods: Eight male participants (mean age 24,13+/-1,55) were randomly exposed to two synchronous vibration frequencies (25Hz and 50Hz) and a non-vibration control procedure during squatting, while monitored with surface EMG.
